preface.title: How can I use an OpenStack cloud?
preface.para: As an OpenStack cloud end user, you can provision your own resources within the limits set by administrators. You can set up access and security for your instances through security group rules and keypairs. You can launch and manage instances, create and manage volumes, images, and snapshots, and track usage. This guide shows you how to interact with a cloud by using the and .
The dashboard, also known as horizon, is a Web-based graphical interface that enables cloud administrators and end users to manage various OpenStack resources and services. .

The command-line clients let you run simple commands to create and manage resources in a cloud and automate tasks by using scripts. Each of the core OpenStack projects has its own command-line client.

However, these are not the only ways to interact with OpenStack resources and services. After you learn how to use the dashboard and the command-line clients, this guide shows you how to access the OpenStack APIs indirectly through cURL commands or open SDKs, or directly through the APIs. You can automate access or build tools to manage resources and services by using the native OpenStack APIs or the EC2 compatibility API.
To use the OpenStack APIs, it helps to be familiar with HTTP/1.1, RESTful web services, the OpenStack services, and JSON or XML data serialization formats.

section.title: OpenStack concepts
section.para: Instances are virtual machines that run inside the cloud.

You can launch an instance directly from one of the available OpenStack images or from an image that you have copied to a persistent volume. The OpenStack Image Service provides a pool of images that are accessible to members of different projects.
